oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Seneca Lake Steamers at Geneva
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Steamers were a popular way to travel across Seneca Lake for approximately fifty years during the later half of the nineteenth century with the Seneca Lake Steam Navigation Company being one of the most prominent companies associated with this venture. The steamers would carry passengers and freight on a regular schedule, stopping at many ports and docks on Seneca Lake. The Otetiana Steamer Ship was constructed in 1883 by William B. Dunning. The Otetiana was used for some time as a tour boat until it rotted through and sank at dock in Geneva in 1909. The second steamer shown, the Onondaga, was a steamer on Seneca Lake until a fateful series of events brought about its destruction. In the summer of 1898, the out of service Onondaga was used as a quarantine vessel for the Joshua Simpkins Opera Company after it was rumored a member of their troupe had developed smallpox. The troupe took this all in stride and played concerts from the boat's deck. After their eventual departure, the ship was thoughly cleaned, but rather than being put back into service, it was blown up on September 14th, 1898, by William H. Herendeenas part of a gesture and spectacle commemorating both the explosion of the Maine off the Cuban coast an event which preceded the beginning of the Spanish-American War as well as a celebration of the end this war.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Salisbury, Elon Galusha, b. 1852
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Lake steamers--Seneca Lake (N.Y.)
Transportation

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: St. Peter's Church - Geneva
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This large Church Building was designed by Richard Upjohn and completed in 1870. Upjohn's son Richard Mitchell Upjohn then designed the bell tower after his father's death in 1878. St. Peter's Church was built as a memorial to Bishop William Delancy, and the church building's consecration ceremonies, attended by approximately 3,000 people, spanned an entire week. This building stand on the corner of Lewis and Genesee street in Geneva.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hobart College Library and Chapel
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This image shows the Demarest Memorial Library, Hobart College's library. The left side of the building with its distinctive doorway was designed by Richard Mitchell Upjohn, a 19th century American architect known for his church buildings, and constructed between 1885 and 1886. An extension was added based on Upjohn's design by Dorchester and Rose in 1894 and 1895 thus completing the right side of the library. St. John's Chapel alongside the library was built in 1862 also based on a Richard Upjohn design. Its construction was funded by William B. Douglas at a cost of nearly $8,000. The chapel was and is still associated with the Episcopal Church.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Laboratories and Dormitories, Hobart College - Geneva
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Merritt and Trinity Hall (L-R). These buildings housed students and classrooms for Hobart and William Smith Colleges. Merritt Hall, located at 670 South Main Street, was built in 1879. The architect who designed the building was Cutler of Rochester. The hall is named for its benefactor Mrs. Julia Douglas Merritt, and was constructed of limestone and some materials from the old Medical College. Merritt Hall housed classrooms and chemical laboratories. The second of the two buildings shown is Trinity Hall which was built in 1837. Its street address is 660 South Main Street. Trinity Hall was designed by Hobart's third president Rev. Benjamin Hale who served from 1836 1858. The principle benefactor of the building's construction was the Episcopalian Church's Trinity Corporation. This building served as both a library and a dormitory.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Salisbury, Elon Galusha, b. 1852

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Located on North Main Street, this church building was constructed in 1894 by William Dove for the Baptist congregation in Geneva. This building is one of many church buildings in Geneva to appear in the National Register of Historic Places.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: North Presbyterian Church - Geneva
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This building housed the Second Presbyterian Church in Geneva which was renamed the North Presbyterian Church in 1874. With its construction having been funded primarily by the congregation and by the following benefactors Henry Maxwell and Local Nurserymen Thompson and Joshua, the newly constructed building was dedicated on July 6, 1879. After the Presbyterian Congregations merged and moved to another building, North Presbyterian it was occupied by the non - denominational Faith Community Church of Geneva, formerly Triumphant Faith.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Geneva's Company B Dinner WWI
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Citizens and city official throw a farewell dinner for Geneva's Company B. at the Geneva Rod and Gun Club. "" A committee, headed by Mayor Rueben Gulvin, seated right in the white coat, planned the dinner. Geneva's most noted citizens volunteered to help, many serving as cooks and waiters. Among the committee were Lynn Henry, P. J. Flanigan, former mayor George Stubbs, H. A. Wheat, James Kennedy, Bill Vogt, Tom Guinan, W. A. Gracey, G. B. Williams, William Moore, Bert Easton and ""Fop"" Witepn and Martin Ouffy,who did the cooking. Then the day the c o m p a ny shipped out, the whole town turned out to see the boys off. Flags' flew throughout the downtown section and everyone lined the streets, cheering and waving flags as the Company marched from the Armory, down Seneca St. to Exchange St. and then to the New York Central station where they boarded trains. 'THE GENEVA TIMES' by Norm Jollow

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Funeral Procession for five local solders who died in WWII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The bodies of five veterans are returned from foreign soil. Headed by an honor guard, the procession is shown going south on Exchange Street. All met death during World War II. Church Bells tolled quietly as the procession of the first war dead traveled to funeral home, the Date was Nov. 8, 1947. The veterans were Pvt. William E. Hill of 10 Park Place; Sgt. Chauncey Dusinberre, Penn Yan; Pvt. Charles L. Dhalle, 28 Jefferson Ave. and Pvt. Charles W. Larzelars of Rochester, a native Genevan.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Geneva's City Hall Cornerstone Laying Ceremony
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Geneva's new city hall was constructed in 1913 by Reinhold Schnirel. This image shows the ceremony surrounding the laying of the building's new cornerstone. Mayor Reuben Gulvin presided over the ceremony on Memorial day May 30th, 1913. Front row Gen. William Wilson, Adolph Gracey at left. Chief Kane, of Police Department fourth from left. Others unknown. At far Right, front row City Attorney and Supreme Court and Ontario County Judge.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Andes Range and Foundry Corp. plant was located on Evans and Lake Streets.It;s primary produce was kitchen stoves; however, during WWII the plant constructed grenades and furniture for Sampson Naval Base.
